Author: Nate Holmes
Keywords: Automotive, Batteries, Mission Critical, Power, Power Storage, Transportation
Article: Battery electric powertrain technology and internal combustion engine (ICE) powertrain technology are fundamentally different. Each requires a completely different set of tests and test capabilities. And when the two technologies are smashed together (ahem, seamlessly integrated) in a hybrid vehicle, test time and cost have the potential to raise dramatically. Itâs translating linear piston motion to rotary torque and balancing power output with flywheels. With the electric powertrain itâs all about electrical test. Itâs power electronics and switching frequencies, voltages and currents, induction and back EMF. Itâs battery capacity and discharge rates and thermal management of inverters and converters and regen power regulation. Itâs motor/generator phase angles and laminate geometries and magnet placement and flux lines. When the two technologies are combined in various ways to form a hybrid powertrain itâs all about integration testing. Itâs control schemes and state diagrams and rule sets governing the interactions between the ICE and electric components. Itâs about ensuring the system responds appropriately in all driving conditions and scenarios.
